review: This product is a source of extreme pleasure and extreme frustration (usually in the same day)...it is one of the most Bi-polar products I have ever used. We bought this device because my early generation LCD is not a smart TV and we wanted to stream Netflix and YouTube to that television. The TV only has DirecTV cable going to it and it is mounted above the fireplace with no room to add a web enabled DVD.Physically the product is extremely well made, it is elegant looking and small. It is inexpensive without any subscription cost. And when it works, it delivers what we had hoped when we bought it. The problem is this device chooses to not work on a completely random schedule hopelessly frustrating us and our three year old who wants to watch Leap Frog on Netflix.For some unknown reason the device will either connect to your device or it will not. Sometimes it will work flawlessly for days, and then sometimes it will connect only after 20 minutes of trying. We are not sure what gets it come back but we do the following to try:+Reset ipad, computer, iphone, etc...+Reset Chromecast+Unhook power to Chromecast+Reset wifi Network+Send kid outside to play and hope he forgets about showI have read dozens of blog postings on this product on Google's sites and other independent sites. It is a common occurrence and I try every remedy that is recommended.  What it boils down to is that you may get a device that works with your system flawlessly or you might get my version, the Sybil of streaming devices.

author: Barbara Bell

review: 06-13-14. It's just over two months since my first Chromecast.  And now, and I have three. The Google Chromecast is three times a winner. Like many of us, I was paying way too much for my TWC cable. With the Chromecast, I've cut my cable bill (big savings) by casting instead, to my three Samsung 1080p HDMI televisions. Casting programs that we enjoy, instead of what's on cable. There are far fewer commercials when casting free internet media. Unlike cable, you are in control. Switch, pause, stop, replay, jump forward. . . commands that  you can't do with cable. Realizing that apps are limited at the moment, there's enough available to keep you busy and entertained. Surely, more and more apps will come in the very near future. If new to casting, it may be a little difficult. Like anything, there is a learning curve. But with practice, and repetition, curiosity, and research, it becomes easier. Chromecast works with my PC, laptop, and Asus tablets. Personally, IMHO, it's better than a Smart TV.
